questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about the deterministic effects of radiation.
  1. It is associated with damage to the DNA of cells.
  2. The severity of these effects is independent of the dose received.
  3. Examples include oligospermia, skin erythema, and epilation.
  4. Below the threshold dose, harmful effects do not occur.
  5. The fetus is more vulnerable to these effects between the 2nd to 20th week of gestation
questions.solution:
Statements 3, 4, and 5 are correct about the deterministic effects of radiation.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: Stochastic effects and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects: 

These effects do not occur below a threshold dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. These effects are associated with radiation-induced killing or malfunction of cells. Skin erythema, epilation, cataracts, and transient oligospermia are a few examples of nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

The fetus is most vulnerable to deterministic effects of radiation between the 2nd and 20th week of gestation. Usually, no deterministic effects occur at a dose below 100 mGy which is the threshold for most imaging modalities.

Stochastic effects: 

Stochastic effects of ionizing radiation are chance events associated with damage to the DNA of cells. They may result in cancer or heritable effects. The incidence of these effects is directly proportionate to the dose of radiation in organs or tissues, but the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. (All or none phenomenon)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of an itchy skin rash. On examination, there are multiple concentric rings with scaling, as shown in the image below. The patient reports intense itching, particularly within the rings, and mentions recent travel to Southeast Asia. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image show numerous concentric rings indicative of Tinea imbricata, resulting from infection by Trichophyton concentricum.

The lesion presents as a scaling ring; centrifugal spread follows, but within the area of central clearing a second wave of scaling soon arises. The process is repeated to give numerous concentric rings. Pruritus is intense and may lead to lichenification. Hypopigmentation may accompany the lesions. It is restricted to the natives of southern Asia, the islands of the South Pacific, Guatemala, southern Mexico, and Brazil.

Other options:

Option A: Trichophyton verrucosum: This dermatophyte fungus typically causes infections known as ringworm in cattle, often transmitted to humans upon direct contact with infected animals. It commonly affects farmers and individuals working in close proximity to livestock.

Option B: Microsporum ferrugineum: Microsporum species are known to cause various types of tinea infections, such as tinea capitis (scalp ringworm) and tinea corporis (body ringworm). 

Option D: Herpes Simplex virus: Herpes Simplex virus infections typically manifest as grouped vesicles or ulcers, often preceded by tingling or burning sensations.

questions.text: Identify the following test.
questions.solution:
The Patch test is shown in the image which is used to confirm the diagnosis of Allergic contact dermatitis.

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning). The patch site is evaluated 1 hour after removal, on day 2 and on day 4 to detect delayed reactions.

Site - Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing, and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may falsely reduce positive test responses in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected. 

The image below shows the patch test.

 

Option A: Skin prick test involves an intradermal puncture through a drop of allergen placed on the skin.

Positive reaction - an urticarial weal, which is apparent after 15 min - 45 min. 

Below image shows skin prick testing.

 

 

Option C: Casoni's test is an immediate Type I hypersensitivity reaction to hydatid fluid to diagnose Echinococcus granulosus infection.

The antigen extracted from the hydatid fluid is sterilised and injected intradermally in one arm. An equal amount of saline is injected in the other arm as control.

Positive reaction - a wheal of about 5cm with multiple pseudopodia-like projection appears within 30mins and disappears in an hour. A secondary reaction of edema and induration appears after 8 hours.

The image given below shows an intradermal injection as done in casoni's test.

 

Option D: Radioallergosorbent test (RAST) is a blood test used for estimation of specific IgE.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient is diagnosed with a fracture of the neck of the femur. T- score on a DEXA scan is -3.0. Which of the following drugs used for this condition acts as a sclerostin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
A T-score of -3.0 in a DEXA scan, along with a fragility fracture, is suggestive of severe osteoporosis. Romosozumab is a monoclonal antibody that acts as a sclerostin inhibitor indicated in this condition.

Radiological osteopenia can be diagnosed from an X-ray where the bone appears less dense than normal. Typical signs are loss of trabecular definition, thinning of cortices, and insufficiency fractures.

DEXA (Dual Energy Xray Absorptiometry) is used to assess bone mass density after a fracture due to a trivial fall or as a preventative measure for adults aged over 60. It has two scores: T-score (compares bone density with that of younger population) and Z-score (compares bone density with the same age group).

Values of T-scores
≥ -1.0 Normal bone density
-1.0 to -2.5 Osteopenia
≤ -2.5 Osteoporosis
≤ -2.5 plus fragility fracture Severe Osteoporosis

 

Treatment options for osteoporosis include:

  • Bisphosphonates - first-line treatment to reduce postmenopausal osteoporosis. It includes oral drugs such as alendronate, risedronate, and i.v. formulations such as zoledronate (given only once per year). They act by reducing bone resorption and the rate of bone turnover.
  • Denosumab (Option C) - a monoclonal antibody that acts against the RANK-L which is essential for promoting osteoclast formation. It is given subcutaneously once every 6 months.
  • Romosozumab - a monoclonal antibody that acts as a sclerostin inhibitor and has been shown to increase bone formation.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide, a synthetic agent given intermittently at low doses to promote bone formation.
  • Strontium ranelate - a drug that promotes bone formation and reduces bone turnover but is used in limited areas due to its adverse effects.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators - Raloxifene, a second-line drug used to reduce future risk of fracture reduction in postmenopausal women.

Other options:

Option B: Odanacatib acts as a cathepsin-K inhibitor which is an enzyme in osteoclast that facilitates bone resorption.

Option D: Pembrolizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that acts against PD1 and can be used in the treatment of melanoma and small-cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score of -2.5 or lower, that is, a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with burning pain on passing urine. He reluctantly admits that he had unprotected sexual intercourse 3 days ago. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient occurring 3 days after unprotected sex point to urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as its incubation period is 1-5 days.

The most common presentation of gonococcal infection in men is acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Pharyngeal and rectal infections can also occur depending on the type of sexual contact.

The primary site of infection in women is the cervix but the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may be involved. Symptoms include excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital and intermenstrual bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia, which has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks. It usually presents with dysuria alone, but mucopurulent discharge can occur.

Option B: Syphilis is primarily a sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema palladium but vertical transmission is also possible. It commonly presents as a hard, painless genital ulcer with induration, followed by the development of rubbery enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes.

Option C: Herpes genitalis is an infection of the genital skin or mucosa with herpes simplex virus HSV 1 and HSV 2. It presents as painful genital ulcers and dysuria. It is usually preceded by a prodrome of general malaise.

questions.text: Among the following, which isotope is used in nuclear scanning?
questions.solution:
Technetium agents based on technetium-99m (Tc-99m) radioisotope are the most frequently used agents in nuclear imaging.

The radioactive technetium can be chelated to a number of different compounds to create specific radiopharmaceuticals and optimize imaging of various structures. The half-life of Tc 99m is 6 hours. It produces gamma rays of 140 keV.

Iodine 125 (I 125), caesium 137 (Cs 137), and iridium 192 (Ir 192) are used in radiotherapy.

questions.solution:
The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine is the paradiscal type.

Pott's spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus) and most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina collapse) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbus.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of the body is affected and spreads through the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) is affected.

The image below shows various parts of the vertebra and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine:

Clinical features of spinal tuberculosis:

  • Back pain, stiffness, and reduced movements are the usual early complaints
  • Cautious gait - a person with spinal tuberculosis will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement
  • Pott's paraplegia
  • Cold abscess
  • Concertina collapse - a type of compression fracture without the involvement of the intervertebral disc
  • Deformity - kyphus and gibbus (gradually increasing prominence).

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation. Which of the following organs is likely to be affected the most?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the ovary is most likely to be affected as it is the most radiosensitive organ. 

Radiosensitivity of pelvic organs is as follows: ovary>rectum>bladder>vagina. Radiation tolerance dose for ovary is 2-3 Gy whereas vagina 90 Gy. Hence, among the given options, the vagina is the most radioresistant organ.

The radiation dose necessary to induce ovarian failure is age-dependent. A single dose of 3-4 Gray can induce amenorrhea in almost all women >40 yrs of age. In young women, oogenesis is much less sensitive to radiation as compared to the elderly. 

Radiosensitivity of various tissues is summed up in the table given below: 

  Most radiosensitive Least radiosensitive
Tissue Bone marrow, Gonads Nervous tissue, Muscle fibers
Blood cells Lymphocytes Platelets
Stages of cell cycle G2M interphase S phase
Cell types Rapidly dividing Quiescent
Ocular structure Lens Sclera
Layer of retina Rods Ganglion cell layer

The skin is most commonly affected due to radiation. Stratum basalis is the layer of the skin most affected.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients on monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI) + selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) can develop serotonin syndrome, which is characterized by fever, clonus, hyperreflexia, and tremors.

Serotonin syndrome can occur with any drug that increases 5-HT levels (e.g., MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA, and dextromethorphan). Coadministration of these drugs results in increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels, which are responsible for the autonomic symptoms seen in serotonin syndrome.

It is characterized by 3 A’s:

  • Neuromuscular hyperActivity- clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure
  • Autonomic stimulation - hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhea 
  • Agitation

Treatment: Cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist).

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with a known case of hypothyroidism presents with pain and burning of the lateral half of the palm. On examination, her palms appear as shown below and Phalen's test is positive. What is the likely structure under which the affected nerve is compressed?
questions.solution:
The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is due to compression of the median nerve where it passes under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.

Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the distribution of the median nerve. There may be a weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Tinel's sign will be positive. This sign is elicited by percussing over the median nerve, reproducing symptoms. In Phalen's test,  the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion for 60 seconds.

Carpal tunnel syndrome can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

The following image shows Phalen's test.

Other options:

Option A: Ligament of Struthers connects the medial epicondyle and the humerus. It is associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve and produces similar symptoms as carpal tunnel syndrome. However, Phalen's test is negative.

Option B: Bicipital aponeurosis is the insertion of the biceps in the cubital fossa. It is also associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve. Phalen's test is negative.

Option C: The ulnar nerve can get compressed while passing through Guyon's canal.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall onto an outstretched hand. Identify the cast given below that was used to manage the patient's injury.
questions.solution:
The cast applied to a patient in the glass-holding position is known as the scaphoid cast/glass-holding cast. It is used to treat scaphoid fractures.

To apply a scaphoid cast, the wrist is held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb is in abduction and slight flexion, as if a glass is being held between the index finger and thumb. It extends from just below the elbow to just proximal to the metacarpal necks of the digits. On the thumb, the cast extends to just proximal to the interphalangeal joint.

Scaphoid fracture presents with pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist. A fall on an outstretched hand could result in such a fracture. The fracture can be confirmed (when an x-ray does not show a fracture) if there is pain elicited in the anatomical snuff box on the radial border of the wrist.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and trethowan's sign seen in the x-ray are suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE) occurs during a period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip are decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrants formed by Hilgenreiner’s line and Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner's line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with ventricular septal defect is posted for corrective surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for induction in this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a child undergoing cardiac surgery, sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for induction.

Halothane and sevoflurane are non-pungent and are less likely to irritate the airway or cause breath-holding or laryngospasm during induction. Hence, halothane and sevoflurane are most suited for use in induction among pediatric patients.

Sevoflurane is less frequently associated with significant myocardial depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias which are seen with halothane. Hence, sevoflurane is preferred over halothane, especially in all cardiovascular surgeries in the pediatric age group.(Option D)

Halothane sensitizes the heart to catecholamines, therefore careful reduction in the epinephrine dose in local anesthetic solutions must be followed. 

Following induction, isoflurane and sevoflurane are the most commonly used inhalation agents for maintenance. 

Options A & C- Desflurane and isoflurane are pungent compounds that irritate the airway and may lead to increased airway resistance, breath-holding, and laryngospasm which make them a poor choice for induction.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of recurrent patellar dislocation. Which of the following would not be a cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Patella baja is an abnormally low-lying patella and is not responsible for recurrent dislocation of the patella.

Causes for recurrent dislocation of the patella include:

  • Excessive joint laxity as in connective tissue disorders like EDS, Marfan's syndrome
  • Patella alta - the patella is high-lying in the shallow part of the inter-condylar groove
  • Trochlear dysplasia
  • Small patella
  • Genu valgum

Given below is a lateral radiograph of the knee joint showing the Insall-Salvati index. This is the ratio of the patella tendon length (LT) to the length of the patella (LP). 

  • In patients with high-lying patella, the ratio is above 1.2. This is known as patella alta. 
  • In patients with low-lying patella, the ratio is below 0.8. This is known as patella baja.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with a bone tumor showing a sunburst appearance on imaging?
questions.solution:
A bone tumor with a sunburst appearance on imaging is most likely osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

Option A: Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor is commonly seen in the age group of 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B: Osteoid Osteoma

The image shows presence of metadiaphyseal cortical osteoid osteoma involving the upper end of the femur with radiolucent nidus surrounded by cortical sclerosis.

Nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma.

Image:

  • Black arrow - Nidus
  • White arrow - Cortical sclerosis

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years involving the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus.

X-ray shows onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was in a major RTA 6 weeks back. Since then he has been experiencing frequent intrusive flashbacks and nightmares about the incident. He avoids the place where the accident occurred. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month are suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder(PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD.

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

Option B: Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to upto 1 month after the trauma.

Option C: Persistent complex bereavement disorder occurs after the death of a loved one. Since the death, for 12 months or more, the individual may experience persistent yearning/longing for the deceased, intense sorrow, emotional pain, preoccupation with the deceased, and the circumstances of the death.

questions.text: During recovery from anaesthesia, which of the following drugs is used for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor commonly used during reversal of anaesthesia.

Reversal agents commonly used in clinical practice:

Cholinesterase inhibitors - Neostigmine (most common), edrophonium, and pyridostigmine.
Sugammadex, a cyclodextrin, is the first selective relaxant binding agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.
L-cysteine causes the inactivation of gantacurium.

Other options:

Option B, C:  Anticholinergic drugs like glycopyrrolate and atropine are not used for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade. They only attenuate the undesirable muscarinic effects of anticholinesterase reversal agents. 

Option D: Propofol is a barbiturate group of drug which is used for induction of anaesthesia.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-week-old neonate with lesions over the body and arms. On examination, thin-walled superficial vesicles are noted as shown in the image below. A disorder of the eccrine sweat gland is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows clear, thin‐walled, superficial vesicles 1–2 mm in diameter resembling drops of water, without any associated erythema. It is suggestive of miliaria, a disorder of eccrine sweat glands. 

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions, resulting in a leakage of sweat into the epidermis (miliaria crystallina and miliaria rubra) or dermis (miliaria profunda).

Other options: 

Option A: Fox-Fordyce disease or apocrine miliaria is the obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum.

Option B: Bromhidrosis is characterized by foul-smelling sweat usually due to infection of apocrine glands.

Option C: Milia, also known as “milk spots” are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts, located over the face usually. They resolve spontaneously without scarring and require no treatment.

Milia and miliaria may sound similar but are actually different from one another. Milia are epidermal inclusion cysts usually located on the face whereas miliaria is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland and is usually located on the body and arms. The clue given in the question is that the condition is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland. Hence, the answer is miliaria.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A patient is undergoing a pre-anesthetic evaluation, and an image of their mouth is provided. Based on the modified Mallampati score, which class does this patient fall into?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the faucial pillars, uvula, and the soft palate are all visible, so it is classified as class I according to the modified Mallampati score. 

The modified Mallampati score is used to assess the difficulty of endotracheal intubation in a patient.

The patient is seated upright with the neutral position of the head, open mouth, and protruded tongue and the patient is asked to not speak. The classification is done based on the visibility of structures through the mouth in this position. The Mallampati classification modified by Samsoon and Young is as follows:

  • Class I: Faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate are visualized.
  • Class II: The base of the uvula, fauces and soft palate are visualized (Option c).
  • Class III: Only the soft palate and base of uvula are visualized (Option b).
  • Class IV: Only the Hard palate is visualized(Option a).

Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate a more difficult laryngoscopy and subsequent intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of excess uncontrollable worry over daily life activities, finances, and his health for the past 2 years. Because of this, he feels restless most of the time. He also complains of fatigue and disturbed sleep. Which of the following screening tools is useful for identifying this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a generalised anxiety disorder(GAD). The GAD-7 scale is used in the assessment of generalized anxiety disorder. 

When assessing for GAD, clinical professionals look for the following according to the DSM-5 (and ICD-11) criteria: 

  • The presence of excessive anxiety and worry about a variety of topics, events, or activities.
  • Worry occurs more often than not for at least six months and is clearly excessive.
  • The worry is experienced as very challenging to control.
  • The worry in both adults and children may easily shift from one topic to another.
  • The anxiety and worry are accompanied by at least three of the following physical or cognitive symptoms (In children, only one of these symptoms is necessary for a diagnosis of GAD):
  • Edginess or restlessness
  • Tiring easily; more fatigued than usual Impaired concentration or feeling as though the mind goes blank
  • Irritability (which may or may not be observable to others)
  • Increased muscle aches or soreness
  • Difficulty sleeping (due to trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, restlessness at night, or unsatisfying sleep)

Other options:

Option A: Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9) is a tool used to assess depressive symptoms in patients with major depressive disorder. 

Option B: CHAT checklist is used in autism (CHecklist for Autism in Toddlers).

Option D: Confusion assessment method (CAM) is a bedside screening test used in the diagnosis of delirium.

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image used for patients with COVID-19 infection.
questions.solution:
The mask in the image is a non-rebreathing mask (NRBM). It can be used for patients with COVID-19 infection.

A NRBM has a reservoir bag attached to the mask in order to provide additional reservoir volume. In addition, there is a valve attached, which provides a unidirectional flow of gases. Flutter valves on the side ports prevent room air entrainment, while a valve incorporated between the mask and the reservoir bag prevents the entry of the exhaled gases.

NRBM can provide the highest FiO2 of 0.9 to 1.0. without intubation at the fresh gas flow of 12-15 L/min. They are used for preoxygenation before intubation and post-extubation in covid patients. 

Other options:

Option A: The venturi mask is a high-flow, fixed-performance device that delivers a specific oxygen concentration to the patient. It is a color-coded device that connects to the oxygen tubing distally and has a nozzle connecting to a mask proximally. Oxygen flows through a central constriction inside the device. Room air enters through surrounding apertures which dilutes the oxygen to the required concentration. The venturi mask is based on Bernoulli's principle. 

Option B: Hudson mask is a simple face mask that delivers oxygen without forming a tight seal against the patient's face. There are holes on either side of Hudson's mask. This provides air entrainment, meeting the peak inspiratory flow and venting out the expired gases.

Option C: A nebulizer is used to deliver drugs to the breathing system. It generates an aerosol, producing droplets of varying sizes. It is shown below.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of fever, myalgia, severe arthralgia, and nose hyperpigmentation (chik sign) points towards a diagnosis of chikungunya. 

Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease. It helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection. It most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It appears as the fever subsides.

Chikungunya fever is due to infection with Chikungunya virus, spread by mosquitos and direct contact between humans. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors.

It presents as an acute onset of fever, arthralgia, and myalgia with other flu symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and nausea. A maculopapular rash develops, which is more pronounced on the trunk. The rash may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, however, a definitive diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM antibodies in the serum with ELISA or RT-PCR.

Treatment is supportive with acetaminophen and NSAIDs. The rash can be managed with saline compresses and emollients. Persistent non-healing ulcers can be managed by topical or systemic antibiotics. Most of the skin lesions resolve within 2 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Melasma is a common skin condition causing dark, irregular patches on the face, often triggered by sun exposure, hormonal changes, or pregnancy. It typically affects the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip.

The following image shows the hyperpigmentation of the face seen in melasma. 

Option B: Melanocytic papillomatous nevi are acquired dermal nevi that are very common. They protrude from the skin surface and may be pigmented or skin-coloured. Upon histological examination, they exhibit nevus cell nests in the dermis. Therapy consists of excision, shave excision, or laser therapy. 

Option C: Actinic keratosis is a pre-malignant lesion that consists of crusty, scaly patches of skin. It is associated with UV light exposure and is therefore associated with solar damage to the surrounding skin. 

The following image shows the scaly patches of skin suggestive of actinic keratosis of the scalp.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about eutectic mixture of local anesthetic (EMLA)?

choices.text: It provides analgesia up to a depth of 2 mm
It is made of Lignocaine and ropivacaine

questions.solution:
The true statement about EMLA(eutectic mixture of local anesthetic) is methohemoglobinemia is a side effect .

EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anaesthetic) is a topical mixture containing prilocaine. The risk of methemoglobinemia is increased in neonates with metabolic disorders or in those receiving drugs that can impair the reduction of methemoglobin. Methemoglobinemia can develop when high doses of prilocaine are administered, typically over 600 mg. 

It is an eutectic(in fixed proportions) mixture, not necessarily equal (Option C). It consists of a 1:1 mixture of 2.5% lidocaine (Option A) and 2.5% prilocaine, not ropivacaine (Option D)

EMLA can provide adequate dermal analgesia for procedures like:

  • Split skin-graft harvesting
  • Venipuncture
  • Intravenous cannulation in children
  • Laser skin treatments
  • Lithotripsy
  • Circumcision

EMLA cream should not be used on mucous membranes, broken skin, infants younger than 1 month of age, or patients with a predisposition to methemoglobinemia. EMLA is applied 45-60 minutes before the procedure with an occlusive dressing. It provides analgesia up to a depth of 5 mm (Option A) that lasts for 1-2 hours.

Other side effects include- blanching of the skin, erythema, and oedema.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with academic and behavioral problems at school over the past year was diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. Which of the following neurotransmitters plays a key role in the pathophysiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
Dopamine has been hypothesized as the key neurotransmitter involved in the pathophysiology of attention-deficit hyperactive disorder.

The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) because of its high utilization of dopamine and its reciprocal connections with other brain regions involved in attention, inhibition, decision-making, response inhibition, working memory, and vigilance. Apart from dopamine, imbalances in the levels of norepinephrine also play a role in this disorder.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition affecting children, adolescents, and adults around the world, characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention, and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. They often have significant impairment in academic functioning as well as in social and interpersonal situations.

The clinical features of ADHD are :

  • Inattention- difficulty focusing, distractibility, not listening or following instructions, failure to finish tasks, forgetfulness, losing/misplacing objects.
  • Hyperactivity- fidgety, unable to sit still, as though driven by a motor, hyper-talkative, interrupts, blurts out answers.
  • Impulsivity- action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization, jumping up in class.
  • Other symptoms may include memory and thinking deficits and specific learning disabilities. 

A variety of medications and behavioral interventions are used to treat ADHD. The most widely used medications are methylphenidate, d-amphetamine, and other amphetamines. These drugs are stimulants that affect the level of the neurotransmitter dopamine at the synapse. Interventions used to treat ADHD include several forms of psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, social skills training, support groups, and parent and educator skills training. A combination of medication and psychotherapy is more effective than either treatment alone.

Other Options:

Option A. Serotonin is involved in the pathophysiology of conditions like depression, mania, schizophrenia, and anxiety.

Option B. Acetylcholine levels are implicated in diseases like Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and Huntington's disease. 

Option D. Gamma amino butyric acid (GABA) level fluctuations are seen in diseases like schizophrenia, Huntington's disease, and various forms of epilepsy.

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents is most appropriate for a patient with cardiac disease?
questions.solution:
Etomidate is considered to be the most appropriate induction agent for cardiac patients. 

Etomidate has minimal effect on cardiovascular function due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptors. They act on alpha 2 adrenoreceptors and increase blood pressure which helps to maintain cardiovascular stability after the induction. 

Etomidate is the induction agent of choice in patients with cardiovascular disease, reactive airway disease, and intracranial hypertension,

Due to its unique hemodynamic stability, it is used as a short-term sedative in hemodynamically unstable patients like patients requiring cardioversion or in patients with unstable angina for minor operative procedures.

Long-term use of etomidate in trauma or terminally ill patients will cause a reversible inhibition on 11 beta-hydroxylase which decreases cortisol production and increase 11 deoxycorticosterone. This results in adrenocortical suppression.

Other options:

Option A- Ketamine has a stimulatory effect on the sympathetic nervous system and results in increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This leads to an increase in myocardial oxygen consumption and so it is contraindicated in ischemic heart disease.

Option C- Propofol is a myocardial depressant agent. It reduces sympathetic activity, leading to vasodilatation that results in a reduction of blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

Option D- Thiopentone is also a myocardial depressant agent. It causes peripheral vasodilatation, reduction in the ventricular filling, negative inotropic effect, and reduction in a sympathetic outflow from CNS. this results in a reduction in blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: The empty delta sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The empty delta sign is a CT sign of cerebral venous thrombosis.

The 'empty delta' sign is a CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where the thrombus becomes less dense and the contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) within the sinus lumen. It is only described with contrast-enhanced CT-scan (CECT) or MRI with contrast (not with non-contrast CT(NCCT) or non-contrast MRI).

On doing an NCCT scan, an acutely thrombosed sinus appears hyperdense and expanded. This is called the 'delta sign'.

questions.text: On being asked "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?" the patient replies "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa." What is this type of response known as?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is tangentiality. The patient has given a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly; it is tangential. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

 Tangentiality is a formal thought disorder.

Symptom Description
Circumstantiality Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point
Clang associations Thoughts are associated by the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming or assonance)

Derailment

(loose associations)

 A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.
Flight of ideas A succession of multiple associations so that thoughts seem to move abruptly from idea to idea; often (but not invariably) expressed through rapid, pressured speech.
Neologism The invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.
Perseveration Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas.

questions.text: An 11-year old boy presented with pain and swelling around his knee. His radiograph is as shown below. Biopsy revealed blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an 11-year old boy with pain and swelling and radiograph findings showing lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the upper tibia and biopsy showing blood-filled cystic spaces leads to the diagnosis of an aneurysmal bone cyst.

An aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones comprising blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common between the age group of 5-20 years with equal male: female distribution. They occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, and humerus. It may occur on the posterior elements of the spine.

Patients usually present with pain and swelling. In cases of spinal involvement, neurologic manifestations can be seen due to nerve root impingement and neurological impairment.

Diagnosis:

A plain radiograph shows an expansile, lytic lesion in the metaphysis. MRI reveals a typical cystic lesion and numerous intralesional septations along with fluid-fluid levels. A biopsy would reveal blood-filled cystic spaces with fibrous septations which might consist of woven bone.

Treatment:

Curettage and bone grafting are done in most cases. Arterial embolization is preferred in cases where curettage is extremely difficult. Low-dose radiation is also effective but avoided in view of potential malignant transformation.

Other options:

Option B- Osteoclastoma (giant cell tumor) is a benign but locally aggressive tumor. It usually affects young adults with a peak incidence in the age group of 20-45 years. A plain radiograph reveals an eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesion in the epiphysis. There is minimal calcification within the tumor. Biopsy reveals osteoclast-like giant cells scattered among round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells.

Option C- Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. Radiograph and MRI would reveal pedunculated bony protuberance with a stalk (as shown below) or some lesions with a broad sessile base. Histology shows the cap composed of benign hyaline cartilage covered with a perichondrium, disorganised growth plate and endochondral ossification in the stalk and inner portion of the head. 

Option D- Simple bone cyst is a unilocular cystic bone cavity that is filled with serous or serosanguinous fluid. It presents most commonly in the first two decades of life. The most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis most commonly affecting metaphysis close to the physis. On the radiograph, a centrally located, lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen. Histology shows connective tissue lining with foci of reactive bone.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic female with an HbA1c value of 9%  requires an emergency fasciotomy in her right leg. Under what ASA PS classification would you place her?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, the patient would be placed under ASA 3 grading of ASA PS classification.

American Society of Anesthesiologists(ASA) classification is used to define relative risk prior to conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia. It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA grade III includes patients with severe systemic disease that causes significant functional limitations. This category encompasses individuals with one or more moderate to severe conditions, such as poorly controlled diabetes, like in this patient who has a high HbA1c level, or hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), morbid obesity (BMI ≥40), active hepatitis, alcohol dependence or abuse, an implanted pacemaker, moderate reduction in ejection fraction, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on regular dialysis, premature infants with a post-conceptual age (PCA) <60 weeks, or a history of myocardial infarction (MI), stroke (CVA), transient ischemic attack (TIA), or coronary artery disease (CAD) with stents placed more than three months ago.

Other options :

Option A: ASA 1 includes normal healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use patients.

Option B: ASA 2 includes patients with mild systemic disease without substantive functional limitations. Eg: current smoker, social alcohol drinker, pregnancy.

Option D: ASA 4 includes patients with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life. Eg: recent ( < 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents, ongoing cardiac ischemia or severe valve dysfunction, severe reduction of ejection fraction, sepsis, DIC, ARD or ESRD not undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

questions.text: A patient with obsessive-compulsive disorder picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face, as given in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This given image shows acné excoriée on the chin of a male with compulsive picking of the face using nail pliers and tweezers.

Acné excoriée is regarded as a self‐inflicted skin condition in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is mostly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are: 

  • Body dysmorphic disorder - Some patients have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Eating disorders - reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenaged age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Option B: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face and presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

Options C: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses which commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne mechanica describes acne that occurs at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet resulting in comedo formation. Examples include ‘fiddler’s neck’, which may occur on the neck of violin players, and is characterized by well‐defined plaques with the presence of comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient comes with chronic right shoulder pain. While examining the patient, the following test elicits weakness in the right shoulder. Which of the following muscles/tendons is implicated here?
questions.solution:
The test depicted in the image is the empty can test and the muscle/tendon implicated here is the supraspinatus.

In this test, the patient is asked to resist the downward force by the examiner, when the arms are in the position of 90° abduction, 30° flexion, and complete internal rotation(as if emptying a can, hence the name of the test). The result is positive if the affected side is weaker than the normal side and indicates a tear in the supraspinatus tendon.

Other options:

Option B: Infraspinatus – Resisted external rotation - The patient flexes elbows to 90 degrees and stands holding his/her arm close to the body. The patient then externally rotates both arms while the examiner applies resistance; lack of power on one side signifies weakness of infraspinatus. 

Option C: Teres minor cannot be assessed separately. But it can assessed along with infraspinatus as they both perform external rotation of the shoulder joint. ‘Lag sign’ and the ‘Drop sign’ are used for this purpose.

The lag sign is performed by asking the patient to lift his arms slightly away from the body and place them in maximum external rotation. A positive test is elicited when the patient cannot maintain that position on one side and allows the arm to drift into a more neutral position. This suggests a tear of the infraspinatus, teres minor, or supraspinatus. 

The drop sign is similar, here the arm is in 90 degrees of abduction, the elbow flexed to 90 degrees and the arm maximally externally rotated. When the examiner lets go, the patient would normally hold that position, but if the arm ‘drops’, it denotes a positive test

Option D: Subscapularis –Lift-off test - The patient places one arm behind his or her back with the dorsum of the hand resting against the mid-lumbar spine. The patient’s hand is lifted off the back and the patient is told to hold it there. The inability to do this signifies subscapularis weakness.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days presenting with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal.

The clinical features of delirium tremens are as follows:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension, and sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits or malabsorption.

It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C: Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D: Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the OPD with the following deformity. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given X-ray of a child with abnormally approximated knees, divergent ankles, and increased intermalleolar distances depicts genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees of physiological outward deviation (valgum). Any increase in angle can result in Genu valgum or knock knee where knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.

Intermalleolar distance has been used to assess the degree of genu valgum. It is the distance between the medial malleoli in a standing patient with touching medial femoral condyles. Intermalleolar distances greater than 8 cm are considered pathologic.

Children start developing physiologic genu valgum by age 2, and it becomes most prominent between ages 3 to 4. After that, it typically decreases to a stable, slightly valgus position by age 7 years. Other causes include

  • Bilateral Genu Valgum: Physiologic genu valgum, skeletal dysplasia, metabolic bone diseases, osteoarthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Unilateral Genu Valgum: Trauma, tumors, and infection.
Osteoarthritis of the knee Rheumatoid arthritis of the knee
Genu varum more common Genu valgum more common
Subchondral sclerosis  Periarticular osteopenia 
No soft tissue swelling  Soft tissue swelling (pannus)
Osteophytes No osteophytes 
Hard and bony joint Soft, warm, and tender joint
Rheumatoid factor negative Rheumatoid factor positive

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at the knee joint with backward bending.

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman appears uninterested in taking care of her 5-week-old baby. Her sleep is disturbed and she feels fatigued. She is irritable and complains of having suicidal thoughts. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a postpartum female with complaints of disturbed sleep, fatigue, and suicidal thoughts is suggestive of postpartum depression. 

Postpartum depression is characterized by a depressed mood, excessive anxiety, insomnia, anhedonia, and a change in weight, usually within the first 12 weeks postpartum.

There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby, which is not present in postpartum blues.

A minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder (SIGECAPS - Sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation) along with anhedonia must be present.

Symptoms should persist for > 2 weeks to make the diagnosis of post-partum depression.

Disturbed sleep and fatigue, are common physiological postpartum findings.

Other options:

Option B: Postpartum blues typically develop within one week of delivery. Symptoms include changes in mood, sudden crying outbursts, and a lack of interest in the baby.

Option C: Post-partum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset is 2-3 weeks postpartum. The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by signs such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation. Lithium, often in combina­tion with an antidepressant, is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Episodes of delirium in the postpartum period are characterized by a fluctuating level of awareness or attention. In this patient, there is no altered sense of awareness.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on his shins for the past 3 months. The patient also gives a history of chewing tobacco for 20 years. She occasionally drinks alcohol and smokes. On examination, the lesions are seen as in the image below. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and characteristic lesions showing fine white lacework in buccal mucosa called Wickham's striae shown in the image are diagnostic of lichen planus. The first line of management is potent topical corticosteroids like clobetasol propionate ointment 0.05%.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. Various factors that can precipitate the disease are:

  • Viruses like Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpesviruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), Varicella zoster
  • Betel quid which contains areca nut and tobacco leaf
  • Environmental factors like:
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

It is recommended to avoid spicy and acidic foods, as well as avoid tobacco and alcohol.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa are characteristic features and are known as Wickham’s striae.

Histology: Most useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis. Basal epidermal cell degeneration/destruction by dermal CD8+ T lymphocytes is characteristically seen in lichen planus. Other findings are:

  • Hyperkeratosis
  • The degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max-Joseph spaces.
  • Saw-toothed appearance of the Rete ridges
  • Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate is present at the dermo-epidermal junction. 

Other options:

Options A and C: Ciclosporin, and methotrexate are used in third-line management and not first-line management of the disease.

Option D: Oral corticosteroids are used in the second-line management of the disease.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with knee pain in the right knee. The inspection of the knee is shown below. The range of movements is painful and restricted along with a crepitus that is felt during movement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with knee pain and unilateral knee swelling is most likely having osteoarthritis.

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Hip and knee joints
  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

On examination, there is tenderness in the joint. A crepitus is felt on joint movement and the range of movements is painfully restricted. Bouchard's and Heberden's nodes may be palpated in PIP and DIP respectively.

Characteristic features of osteoarthritis seen on plain X-ray are:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

The image below is an X-ray of osteoarthritis showing the presence of osteophytes, narrowing of the joint space (arrow), and subchondral bone sclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. Its onset is around the age of 45-50 years. Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that relieves with activity. It typically starts in small peripheral joints[metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints], is usually symmetric, and progresses to involve proximal joints if left untreated. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger.

Option C: Gout is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males and it usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Clinical features include painful, stiff or swollen joint, deformity of the affected joint (most commonly first metatarsophalangeal joint), and subcutaneous nodules.

The radiograph is normal in the initial stages while it shows erosions, punched-out lesions, and sclerosis with preservation of joint space in the late stages. 

Option D: Pseudogout results from the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate in the joints. It can be associated with hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypophosphatasia, and hypomagnesemia. It presents features similar to acute gout.

Synovial fluid analysis under polarized light shows

  • Negatively birefringent needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals in gout
  • Positive birefringent rhomboid-shaped calcium pyrophosphate crystals in pseudogout. 

This patient's age and history are more suggestive of osteoarthritis. The knee joint is the most commonly affected in pseudogout but in this age group, osteoarthritis is a more common disease compared to pseudogout.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with numerous itchy skin lesions on his chest and back which show characteristic collarette scales. 2 weeks prior to this he had noticed a round, scaly, erythematous lesion as shown in the image given below, on his thigh. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: More common in children and young adults
Associated with viruses like HHV- 6 and HHV-7
Topical steroids can be used to relieve pruritus

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing a herald patch, is suggestive of pityriasis rosea. It is an acute self-limiting condition, with very low recurrence rates. 

Pityriasis rosea/pityriasis circinata is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults.

Even though the exact cause is unknown, T-cell mediated immunity and infectious etiology are thought to be responsible for this condition. An association with infectious agents like human herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and human herpesvirus-7 (HHV-7) has been found recently.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodrome of a sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbance, fever or arthralgia.
  • Herald patch - Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk or neck covered by fine scales

The image given below shows a herald patch.

  • After 5-15 days, it turns into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales. 
  • These secondary lesions occur as macules and papules that are elliptical or ovular, symmetric, and commonly involve the thorax, back, and abdomen.
  • It is followed by a marginal collarette of scale with a central wrinkling and atrophy. The collarettes of the scales are attached peripherally. It is also called a hanging curtain sign.

The image given below shows collarette scales.

  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of skin tension parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.

 The images given below show a Christmas tree pattern along the lines of skin tension on the back and the chest.

The rashes of pityriasis rosea usually resolve by 8 weeks.

Dermatoscopy shows:

  • Yellowish background-color
  • Peripheral arrangement of the scales
  • Patchy distribution of loosely arranged dotted vessels

Histopathology shows:

  • Superficial perivascular dermatitis with focal parakeratosis, hyperplasia and spongiosis in the epidermis.
  • Extravasated red blood cells along with a perivascular infiltrate and subcorneal pustules are seen in the dermis

No treatment is required for asymptomatic cases. Application of irritants to the skin and tanning should be avoided, since it may result in pigmentary changes. Emollients and antihistaminics are useful to relieve the itching. If symptomatic, various agents are used like:

  • First-line agents: If severe pruritus or poor cosmetic appeal is present
    • Topical steroids
    • Narrowband UV-B therapy
  • Second-line agents: For a rapid resolution of the lesions, in view of the probable infectious aetiology.
    • Antivirals like acyclovir
    • Macrolides like erythromycin

Pityriasis rosea within the first few weeks of gestation may cause premature delivery and fetal demise. Pityriasis rosea-like eruptions were reported after ingestion of drugs like gold, captopril, aspirin, metronidazole and clonidine and after vaccinations like BCG, influenza, diphtheria, hepatitis B, and Pneumococcus.

Its is a fine, peripherally attached and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in Pityriasis rosea.
