questions.text: The following waveform when seen on a capnograph suggests?
questions.solution:
The image in the given question shows a capnograph with a sudden and progressive increase in ETCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. 

Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic hypermetabolic disease of the muscle. It occurs due to a mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19. It is an ion channel responsible for calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Clinical features include, hypercarbia, hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, arrythmia, hypertension. Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice. It is given rapidly at a dose of 2.5 mg/ kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes till the attack subsides.

Other options :

Option B: Rebreathing of CO2 would result in failure of the inspired CO2 to return to zero in the capnograph.

Option C: Tracheal intubation would show a normal capnograph.

Option D: Esophageal intubation would initially detect some CO2 because of swallowed air in the stomach which later returns to zero.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria; the obtained x-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a homogenous and ground-glass-like calcification of the kidney, appearing like putty. In a patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria, the given image finding points towards a diagnosis of putty kidney.

The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is, thus, always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed by a tuberculin test or examination of at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine for acid-fast bacilli. The isolated bacilli are stained with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

CT is the most sensitive modality and the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations, which are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures.
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis.
    • Mural thickening and enhancement.
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma.
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis.
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done.

Other options:

Option B: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism. 

Option C: Staghorn calculus usually occurs in association with urinary infection with Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus and is not a cause for sterile pyuria. 

Option D: Psoas calcification is a muscle calcification and might be seen developing after acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was on crutches for a few months after a road traffic accident. After the initial 2 weeks, he complained of an inability to extend his wrist. He achieved complete recovery a few weeks later. What is the mechanism behind this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man not able to extend his wrist after the use of a crutch and complete recovery after a few weeks is suggestive of crutch palsy which is a type of neurapraxia. 

Neurapraxia is a reversible physiological block in nerve conduction. Some types of sensation and muscle power are lost in neuropraxia. The structure of the nerve is not changed and there is complete, spontaneous recovery after a few weeks. Neurapraxia occurs due to segmental demyelination by mechanical pressure. 

Crutch palsy occurs when the radial nerve is compressed in the arm from direct pressure against a firm object (crutch). Other examples of neuropraxia include Saturday night palsy and tourniquet palsy.

Other options:

Option A: Neurotmesis occurs due to the damage in both axon and nerve by a complete section or scarring of a segment in open fractures. A surgical nerve repair is required since spontaneous recovery doesn't take place.

Option B: Axonotmesis occurs due to the damage of axons with preservation of the internal architecture of the nerve. It is seen typically after closed fractures and dislocations. Spontaneous recovery can occur but may take a long time.

Option C: Neurolysis is the surgical removal of fibrotic tissue inside a nerve trunk.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups

  1. Neurapraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neurapraxia:

Reversible physiologic conduction block. Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.

E.g.,Saturday night palsy, torniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

Axonal interruption. Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact.

E.g.,Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

Division of the nerve trunk. Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs.

E.g., Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the image of the scan given below?
questions.solution:
The given MRI of the brain demonstrates a predominantly solid enhancing suprasellar mass with a small cystic component posteriorly suggestive of craniopharyngioma

  • It develops from the persistent remnants of the original connection between Rathke's pouch and the anterior pituitary gland. 
  • Adamantinomatous (children) and Papillary (adults) are two variants of craniopharyngioma.
  • Calcification is characteristic of the adamantinomatous variety and predominates in childhood.
  • These tumours are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components.
  • The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid that is compared to "machine oil".

Symptoms include headache and visual changes (bitemporal hemianopia) as well as endocrinologic abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction and GH deficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Pituitary apoplexy is an acute condition caused usually by hemorrhagic necrosis of the pitutary gland. It shows peripheral enhancement around a non-enhancing infarcted center.

Option B: Pitutary macroadenoma show solid components and demonstrate moderate to bright enhancement.

Option C: Rathke cleft cyst are cysts arising from the embryologic remnants of Rathke pouch in the pituitary gland. They show unicameral cysts (without septations) and homogeneous in signal intensity without a solid component.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man reported that he washes his hands 15-20 times a day, to the point of it taking a toll on his workplace performance. He says this is due to repetitive thoughts that his hands are contaminated with dirt. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The man is suffering from obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), as evidenced by the obsession (doubt that his hands are contaminated), followed by a compulsion (washing his hands way too many times). An obsession with contamination is a common symptom of adult OCD.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions. These recurrent obses­sions or compulsions cause severe distress to the patient. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. A compulsion is a conscious, standardized, recurrent behavior, eg: counting, and checking, and is done in order to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession.

Treatment of OCD includes:

  • Pharmacotherapy: SSRIs or clomipramine
  • Behavioural therapy: Approaches include:
    • exposure and response prevention
    • desensitization
    • thought stopping
    • flooding
    • implosion therapy
    • aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioural and pharmacotherapy is most effective.

Other options:

Option A: Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder characterized by alternating episodes of mania or hypomania and depression. It can affect daily functioning, with symptoms ranging from elevated energy and impulsivity to sadness and fatigue.

Option C: Schizophrenia is a chronic mental disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and impaired functioning. It typically manifests in early adulthood and affects perception, emotion, and behaviour.

Option D: Mania is a state of elevated mood, increased energy, and hyperactivity, often seen in bipolar disorder. It can lead to impulsivity, reduced need for sleep, and impaired judgment.

questions.text: A young male patient is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
The given history of long-standing suspiciousness, not trusting people, and bearing grudges for insults is suggestive of paranoid personality disorder.

Paranoid personality disorder, a part of cluster A personality disorders, is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful of perceived threats and deceit and often read hidden demeaning or threatening meanings into benign remarks. They are reluctant to confide in others due to the fear that the information they provide will be used against them maliciously.

They tend to be extremely jealous, hostile, argumentative, and defensive. Their paranoia prevents them from establishing any overly-involved relationship. They persistently bear grudges and can get irritable and angry easily. They use the defense mechanism of projection by displacing their insecurities on others. 

They may not be willing to accept that they need psychiatric help. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice. Care should be taken by the therapist to not behave defensively if accused of making a mistake. Pharmacotherapy is generally used to deal with anxiety and agitation. Diazepam is used as an anxiolytic while antipsychotics like haloperidol or pimozide may be required to deal with agitation.

Other options:

Option A: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are usually eccentric and isolated. They neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They always choose to be alone and lack close friends. They are emotionally cold and appear indifferent to praise or criticism.

Option B: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder appear odd and strange to surrounding people. They have ideas of reference, odd or magical thinking, inappropriate or constricted affect, and suspiciousness.

Option D: Individuals with histrionic personality disorder have excessive emotional and attention-seeking behavior. They are uncomfortable in situations where they are not the center of attraction. questions.text: A patient presents with joint pain which increases in the early morning when he wakes up and decreases with activity. Examination reveals the following picture (given below) along with inflammation of the wrist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the above image with nail pitting and yellowing of the nails and inflammation of the DIP joints, point to a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disease with joint and nail manifestations apart from the skin. It has silvery scales.

The joint manifestations in psoriasis are referred to as psoriatic arthritis. It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and hence it is associated with HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement.

Other features:

  • Psoriatic nail changes like yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Inflammation of the toes- dactylitis
  • Shortening of toes- telescoping (because of osteolysis)
  • Severe deformity- suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Associated heel pain- suggestive of enthesitis (pain at the sites of ligament/tendon attachment)

The x-ray shows 'pencil in cup' deformity due to tapering of phalanges with cupping of proximal parts. Also all the bones of a single digit maybe involved refered to as ray deformity.

The drug of choice for different types of psoriasis is shown in the pearl below.

The most likely diagnosis for this patient's joint pain, which worsens in the early morning and improves with activity, along with the given picture showing nail changes and inflammation of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, is Psoriatic Arthritis.

Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It is categorized under the seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is often linked to the presence of HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement. 

Some key features associated with psoriatic arthritis:

  • Psoriatic nail changes like yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Inflammation of the toes - dactylitis (sausage appearance).
  • Shortening of toes - telescoping (because of osteolysis)
  • Severe deformity - suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Associated heel pain - suggestive of enthesitis (pain at the sites of ligament/tendon attachment)
  • Radiographic findings, including the "pencil-in-cup" deformity, which results from the tapering of phalanges and cupping of proximal parts.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces of both arms.  Punctate pitting was noted on examining the nails. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of erythematous plaques with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces of arms and punctate pitting of the nails are suggestive of psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type.

  • The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash.
  • The lesions are red, and scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.
  • Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon- describes the appearance of new lesions along the site of trauma (linear lesions)

Nail findings are commonly seen across all types of psoriasis. Patients present with pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. In the case of nail bed involvement subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis can be seen.

The characteristic histopathological finding in psoriasis consists of multiple neutrophilic foci in the parakeratotic stratum corneum i.e Munro’s microabscesses and spongiform neutrophils in the spinous layer of the epidermis i.e spongiform pustules of Kogoj.

The topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management. Phototherapy and oral methotrexate, acitretin, and cyclosporine can also be used.

Other options:

Option B: Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder affecting the skin and mucosal membranes. The lesions of Lichen planus can be described as 5Ps — purple, polygonal, pruritic, plane-topped (flat), papules and are shown in the image below. White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa is a characteristic feature and are known as Wickham’s striae. Nail involvement includes hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, onycholysis, and pterygium unguis due to adhesion between the dorsal nail fold and the nail bed.

Option C: Atopic dermatitis or eczema is a relapsing chronic inflammatory skin disease. Patients present with itchy erythematous papules/ papulovesicular lesions in flexural regions as shown below. Nail involvement is in the form of coarse pitting and ridging. 

Option D: Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults. The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch, which is larger and more conspicuous than the lesions of the later eruption covered by fine scales. Later the center tends to clear and assumes a wrinkled, atrophic appearance and a tawny color, with a marginal collarette of scale attached peripherally, with the free edge of the scale internally - called a Hanging curtain sign.

questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analogue called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell. (So, the patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging).
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner. 
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for the differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumour staging and evaluation of tumour recurrence.

Areas of normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity, and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract (FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems)
  • Brown fat (FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production)
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

Other options:

Option A: 16F-FDG (Fluorodeoxyglucose) is a radiolabeled glucose analogue used in Positron Emission Tomography (PET) to assess metabolic activity in tissues. It is particularly useful for detecting cancer, and infections, and monitoring neurological disorders due to its ability to highlight areas with high glucose consumption.

Option C: Carbon-11 (C-11) is used for certain types of PET imaging, particularly in neurology and oncology.

Option D: Gallium-68 (Ga-68) is used for imaging certain types of neuroendocrine tumours and somatostatin receptor imaging.
